snippet.textDisplay: I cried several times during and after this video and thought for a long time about what I wanted to say. I have watched every video on every LMG channel. I have been a daily watcher for over four years and seen LTT gain over 8 million subscribers since I started watching and I am proud to be one of them. What you have built is amazing and it has helped so many people in so many ways. There were many times when the daily LTT video was the little bit of positivity I needed to get through my day. The knowledge I have gained from these videos has also helped me build my own career. I recommend LTT to people weekly. You have done so much for this industry and your community. You do what you need to to be happy. We're not going anywhere. Love you man.

snippet.textDisplay:
From what I got from this video essentially are:
1) you need a break
2) you love tech but hate the waste and consumerism
3) you made it to your goal
4) you almost sound suicidal

Sounds like you need a vacation.
Please don’t kill yourself.
Time to enjoy your hard work by spending time with your family and working part time. Make minimal videos and let your colleagues be more exposed.
If you think your videos promote waste and consumerism, maybe make a video and add links to places that will buy or recycle old computer parts.
Remind people that the best isn’t always the way to go. But rememver people will always be wasteful whatever you say or do.
Lastly, don’t ever be ashamed of trying to make money especially by people who knock you saying your videos are filled with sponsored crap. It’s how the youtube business is run. If people don’t like it, then they shouldn’t watch youtube.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi Linus

I generally never comment on videos. For me this was a great video. It brought up a lot of memories and feelings. This video touched my tech sole. If you get a chance to read this, great. If you need to pass that is OK too.

I don't know if I am writing you to be a guide or to share my experience with a fellow techie.

A touch about me, so you can relate to my advice or comment. I have worked in personal computer hardware, tech, manager. I started with the apple II and first IBM PC's & industrial automation for 20 Years. I then worked 20 years programming on, PC's, PLC's and mainframes. I have not been able to make a total success of it, tech companies turn over people a lot. I am still a tech guy. Unfortunately I have had to take many jobs to keep alive not paying well or tech. This might have been a good thing as it kept me from burning out. Pass 50 years old and there are not many companies hiring.

You are lucky, like you said, to have such a good family and wife. I am single but have many good family members and friends. I appreciate your being able to vent or explain on camera. I would recommend to start setting up small plans and people to take over parts your work. It is the hardest to do for a top guy that has so many decisions and problems to deal with, along with the day to day work. Once your kids hit 8 you will want to start back to working a bit more. The kids will be with their friends and their activities. It is a slow process with kids and you should have a slow process at work where you can throttle your work load down instead of over clocking it. Ha ha..This will help you and your company when you really do decide to retire.

I have just had to deal with retirement and is now the time. I lost my last job at Lowe's of all places (no biggie). I don't have the financial security like you, but I needed to learn to enjoy life and tech. I am still nervous about retirement but it's enjoyable to be here. I have lost many of my close friends and a few co-workers to death. Sad part of life, but I try to keep the door open for new friends.

I am glad you are not retiring right away, but good that you are thinking about it.

My retirement activities are going to include a bit more fishing and camping. I have been all over the world, so travel is not important to me. I made a plan long ago to be involved with 3D rendering during my retirement. I hope your team puts out a video on the thread-ripper 3990 and best GPU, waiting to see big navi. Talking with my dad, once he is gone, I will be looking to getting a big system. My current alien-ware PC is very old. It's looking like +10k or so for a system but I can wait and see what is out in the next couple of years.

I wish you well with the decisions ahead. Thanks for letting me vent too.

Mark

snippet.textDisplay:
I hardly ever comment, but I’ve been a loyal part of your audience for years now. I think the most endearing and most important quality for me is the level of integrity [and honesty which is directly proportional] which you have engineered into the very fabric and fibre of your company. It has set you and your company into the stratosphere compared to the vast majority of tech-related ventures, and even the wider swathe of “creators” on YouTube.
All of that to say this: thank you for being so very honest with us here. Thank you for trusting us with a piece of you mind and heart; your openness [honesty] is a great strength [even when it feels like weakness]. These thoughts and feelings are valid and incredibly important. We were created to be in relationship[s] and that’s one of the few things that lasts into eternity. Businesses, like kings and empires rise and fall, be they good, bad, or ugly.
I’m not trying to advocate for anything mind you. I just want to lend a voice of validation. The fact that you’re wrestling with this is important and a good sign. Be honest as honest with yourself as you are with others. I’ll be praying that you come to a wise decision. 🙃

snippet.textDisplay:
I've been binging some of your older content the last few days, so this is... unexpected.

Take time off and step back from it all. You're more important than you think; you can't drive yourself into the ground like you do your cars. Take that wife and those kids of yours on a vacation and trust the team you've built to steer the ship in your absence. If you really want to retire to take back control of your life, you do what you feel is best. But the way you talk about your love of tech, I imagine a vacation would be better served because you're going to feel that itch to get back into the swing of things sooner or later.

We'll still be here when that happens. Good luck, whatever you decide, Linus.
snippet.textOriginal:

Hey man keep your chin up, I know what it's like having an Asian girl because I have one myself, and they are very family-oriented and to be honest she's right, your family should come first, but at the same timeI understand why you feel like you have a responsibility to your fans and employees you just have to find the right balance.

if you feel like it's time to pass the torch, go ahead and pass the torch and just pop into your office once a week or however often you feel like you need to so you can be satisfied.
A man definitely needs to take care of his family, but a man also needs to feel fulfillment. If you can find a way to balance the two, you'll be a much better person than most of us!

I'm always in your corner bro 👊

snippet.textDisplay:
I've been a long time follower, watching since early 2014 and having watched every wan show since around that time. If it wasn't for your channel I would have never discovered my love for tech and my desire to study electrical engineering. It has fundamentally changed my life and for the better.

I completely agree with your view on tech, being around it everyday in my personal life and in my degree, I've realised how pointless it all is and how important it is to stop this race to the bottom with cheap, useless tech, that is just there because people are lile why not?

Anyway, I hope you lead your life in the best way you possibly can, but do appreciate the kind of difference you have made through your outreach on youtube, I think we can all attest to that.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Life just happens, what matters is who you do it with." (Paraphrased) I needed that reminder, sincerely thank you Linus.

As for the story about the wish kid, I wholeheartedly believe that should become a driving force in your organization. Pick a new cause on a regular basis (monthly or quarterly) and lean on your fans and generous sponsors to make a difference for someone else or some organization (ex: network upgrade for a nonprofit group).

Edit: Keep the dad humor coming. I relate deeply with you there on top of the love of tech.

Ask your kids and wife if they want you to spend more time with them and youll have a better sense of direction in what to do.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm 70, retired IT and had "retirement moments" a few times over my 50 year. Nobody knows what you should do, but I can give you great advice, take your time, take your time.....


Even better, take a break, don't burn bridges that don't necessarily need to be burned. Spend time with your family.


Death is rough, at my age I've seen a lot of it, nothing we can do, but giving back we can do. Give to charity, build systems for the less fortunate (I still do, no functional gear should be unused).


Your a good person, catch you breath, think about using your skills to help others. Tech isn't evil, if it makes you more money than you need and it bothers you, after your friends and family share your success. Make your success fund good things, don't begrudge it, focus it on what it affords you to do.....share, help others, giver back..........be happy.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey man, I just wanted to comment on your bit in the middle about luxury goods and why you do what you do. Don't underestimate the value of entertainment and inspiration, people need more than just the most utilitarian things in their life. That's why you do this, because you love it, and that's worth a lot. That kid clearly felt it was important even in such a desperate time, it seemed like a small thing to you but sometimes what people need most are the things they find fun, or are just passionately curious about. You add value to your audiences lives just like art does, or games do, even if they aren't obviously practical. You have a hobby demographic, but don't underestimate the support you give to everyone, from your staff building a life they love to someone building their first computer so they can play with their friends. "Fun" is worth a lot more than most people give it credit for.

And if you are concerned about your impact or legacy, the credibility, audience, and mechanisms you've built so far are now so strong you can afford to focus your angle more on what you believe in. Providing responsible information to the public, reducing e-waste, and the right-to-repair are all important topics right now in the tech industry and beyond. Your audience might be interested in flashy hobby-ist products, but I think they do share these values with you, and as a big name in tech media you are in a position to enact more change than you might realize.


Thank you for everything you've done for us over the years already.

snippet.textDisplay:
Everyone has times when they question life and what we’re doing. It reminds us to always ask why. Why do I keep doing this? Sometimes the answer is something big, like getting to do what you love and enjoying your life because of it. Other times, the reason why is simply because you don’t know how, or don’t want to, do anything else. Regardless of the answer, you always need to answer the question. And stand by that answer.

If you don’t feel like you can answer the question right now, then take some time. Step back from what you’re doing. Spend time with your family. Spend time alone.

Just don’t go through more of life without answering the question of why.

snippet.textDisplay:
Commenting on youtube is pointless, but maybe you'll see this.
Linus, your videos and your company do the exact opposite of promoting mindless consumerism. You've taught a generation or three to do their own research and make informed decisions when it comes to technology. Your videos and reviews always focus on best "bang for the buck," what's best for the end-user... us. Not the manufacturer. You've always been honest and provided feedback, and your influence over the tech world enables you to do that.You and your crew can literally be holding the newest Dell model, surrounded by Dell reps in a private room, and straight up tell us why we shouldn't buy it.You've built your empire on sharing and spreading information that may not otherwise be accessible to the common man. 10 million of us go to you first when we need an honest review of the latest monitor or GPU because we know we can trust you and yours to have our best interests in mind, all while presenting the information we need in a short, digestible format.You've revolutionized the ad revenue path on youtube by becoming so influential that sponsors pay for spots in your videos. I'm blocked up by every ad and script blocker on the planet, but I don't mind sitting through your hilariously ham-fisted segues and LTTstore dot com whispers. Because I know that, even with sponsors, you're still telling us the truth about what you think of the products (the whole tunnelbear thing comes to mind.)I'll cut it here, just suffice to say that you don't have to question your legacy or worry that you haven't made an impact on the world. You've become one of, if not the most, important voice for end-users in the world of tech- just by being yourself. AMD won't listen to me, won't listen to a subreddit or forum of people... but if you say something, you can bet they hear you. You're the voice of millions. And I personally thank you for representing me for all these years.
